tossups.question: This author worries about carnies who spin his “Native Companion” friend around on the Zipper so they can look up her skirt in an essay about the Illinois State Fair. Another essay by this author includes a footnote railing against the “Professional Smile” and describes the mean-spirited hypnotist Nigel Ellery and the waiter Tibor. This author described the stress of “stay[ing] conscious and alive” despite “petty, frustrating crap” in a commencement speech titled (*) “This is Water.” An essay by this author begins by listing things he has seen, including “500 upscale Americans danc[ing] the Electric Slide” and “intensities of blue beyond very bright blue.” One of his essays contemplates the ethics of boiling animals alive at a Maine festival. For 10 points, name this author of “A Supposedly Fun Thing I’ll Never Do Again” and “Consider the Lobster,” who also wrote the doorstopper Infinite Jest.
tossups.answer: David Foster Wallace [or DFW, prompt on “Dallas Fort Worth”]

tossups.question: A serial killer named for using these objects claimed to “crave the warmth of [his] native Tartarus” in a public announcement vowing to spare anyone who listened to jazz music; that person terrorized New Orleans’ Italian-American community during his 1919 murder spree. The steamboat Warrior fired upon a surrendering Sauk chief at a battle named for one of these objects, which concluded a conflict begun at the Battle of Stillman’s Run. It’s not a pipe, but many Native American tribes concluded treaty ceremonies with a ritual in which one of these objects was (*) buried in the earth. The town of Fall River, Massachusetts gained notoriety after one of its residents used “forty whacks” of this weapon to kill her parents. Lizzy Borden used, for 10 points, what weapon, an Iroquois version of which is called a tomahawk?
tossups.answer: axes [or hatchet; battle axe; the New Orleans Axeman; the Battle of Bad Axe; tomahawk until mention; yes, this is where the term “burying the hatchet” comes from]

tossups.question: Systems without convection undergoing this process can show Liesegang rings. Ammonium sulfate is used to do this to proteins, and the Hofmeister series arranges salts by their ability to do this to proteins. Whether this process is reversed by the addition of KOH is useful for distinguishing primary or secondary amines in the Hinsberg test. Sodium acetate is used to coat DNA before subjecting it to this process using (*) cold ethanol. The supernatant is what’s left over after this process. This process can be triggered by adding an impurity to a supersaturated solution or adding a common ion, and occurs when the Ksp is really small. For 10 points, name this process in which a solid falls out of solution.

In one work by this artist, a huge cannon shot 20 tons of red wax balls into the corner of a room, creating a bloody-looking mess; in a related piece, a steel plate slowly peeled layers off of a wax hemisphere. This sculptor installed a giant pool of continually spiraling water in Brooklyn Bridge Park, and he created a tower surrounded by steel rings and red scaffolding for the London Olympics. This artist of the ArcelorMittal Orbit recently posted a picture of his middle finger covered in pink dye, flouting a ban made in response to his (*) exclusive rights to the “blackest black” Vantablack. In Kensington Gardens and Rockefeller Center, he placed installations of his enormous, concave Sky Mirror. This sculptor created a reflective, bean-shaped structure in Chicago’s Millennium Park. For 10 points, name this creator of Cloud Gate.

This author claimed that recent novelists had “shown us what it is that we certainly could not do, but as certainly, perhaps, do not wish to do” in “Modern Novels.” This author claimed that human character changed “on or about December 1910” in an essay about “Mrs. Brown” that attacks author Arnold Bennett. One of this author’s books ends with a mother asking “What am I to do with these?” while holding her (*) dead son’s shoes. This author wrote about Paul searching for Minta’s brooch on the beach in a novel where a little boy carefully cuts shapes out of a magazine while thinking about how much he hates his father, a “tyrannical” intellectual based on this author’s father, the academic Leonard Stephen. For 10 points, name this author who created the painter Lily Briscoe in an “elegy” written to exorcise the memories of her parents, To the Lighthouse.

Jonathan Schaffer challenged one account of this phenomenon with the “wizards case,” involving both Merlin and Morgana turning a prince into a frog. Different views of the relata involved in this phenomenon argue that they are events, facts, features, tropes, or aspects. “Trumping” poses problems for accounts of this phenomenon, since it’s a specific form of (*) pre-emption. Thanks to the influence of David Lewis, modern analytic philosophers often refer to this phenomenon in terms of counterfactuals. Kant defined this phenomenon as a category or pure concept of the understanding in an “answer” to David Hume’s attack on the connection between it and effect. For 10 points, name this concept in which one thing happens after and as a result of another thing.

Description acceptable. Avocado accused one of these works of plagiarism after discovering quotes from The Hidden Land by Pamela Dean. After her claim to be the author of one of these works was debunked, Rose Christo lost a book deal for her memoir, in which she claimed she had written one of these works to get publicity for her missing brother. Many of these works include a marriage law, depictions of a character in leather pants, or the protagonist being revealed to have a (*) female twin. An often-mocked one of these works used ideas from the site LessWrong and focused on the title character’s “Methods of Rationality.” “Tom Bombadil” oddly appears in one of these works, as do “Snap” and Diablo. The goth Ebony Dark’ness Dementia Raven Way appears in “My Immortal,” which is, for 10 points, what type of fan work based on a series by J.K. Rowling?

One attempt to create a vaccine for this disease using a 42-amino acid-long peptide was halted in 2002 when it resulted in encephalitis in 6% of the trial patients. Later stages of this disease involve massive nitric oxide release from cells following activation of calcium-sensing receptor. NMDA receptor antagonists such as memantine are used to treat the late-stage symptoms of this disease. Down syndrome patients can exhibit (*) early-onset of this disease due to the overexpression of APP. Arginine-112 and arginine-158 mutations in apolipoprotein E are closely linked to this disease. Tau tangles and beta-amyloid plaques are hallmarks of this disease. For 10 points, name this most common neurodegenerative disease that results in dementia.

The Ostrogothic queen Amalasuntha was supposedly killed while performing this action. Another person who was assassinated while performing this action may have been killed for adulterous relations with her stepson, Crispus. Although it is not religious, participants in this activity were often anointed by slaves called unctores. Constantine allegedly had his (*) wife killed by suffocation while she was performing this activity. The hypocaust was created to help facilitate this activity. This activity usually involved proceeding to the caldarium from the tepidarium and frigidarium—an increase in temperature. The Romans generally performed this activity in public venues called thermae. For 10 points, name this action which someone might use to cleanse their body.
tossups.answer: bathing [or using the baths; accept using thermae before mention; accept clear knowledge equivalents like washing, etc.]

tossups.question: In one legend from this country, a warrior coated his arrows in his own saliva in order to slay a giant centipede. People with completely evil souls are forced to swim through river rapids filled with snakes in this country’s underworld, and people who cross the river with no clothes on have their skin flayed off and hung in a tree. A “modern legend” from this country involves a woman wearing a red mask who asks people, (*) “Am I pretty?”, to which answering either “yes” or “no” will result in a gruesome death. A superstition in this country instructs people to lay out food at night or put coins in a house’s foundation to please benevolent spirits. The many wild cats found in this country are said to age into massive, shapeshifting monsters called bakeneko. For 10 points, name this home of yokai, also called mononoke.

Heckscher argues that in real life, this painting’s subject would likely have stood farther away from the main action, but that he wanted to appear as the reborn version of the author of a book appearing in this painting. Schupbach argues that God’s wisdom is highlighted in this painting’s emphasis on the human hand. This painting is often compared to an earlier one by Thomas de Keyser but has a more varied composition, such as a figure in top standing in front of a scroll and a figure on the right (*) looking at a page of notes. The criminal Aris Kindt is at the center of this work, and a open book by Vesalius is in the bottom right. Seven men in black with white ruffs surround the title figure, who uses forceps to expose the muscles of a dead body’s arm. For 10 points, name this Rembrandt painting where the title physician performs a demonstration.
tossups.answer: The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp

tossups.question: The probability of a particle involved in this process existing before this process takes place is equal to the squared matrix element of the overlap of two wavefunctions and is known as the preformation factor. The kinetic energy of the product of this process is proportional to a quantity relating the masses of inputs to this process; that value is known as the Q-value. The probability of this process occurring can be calculated by applying the WKB approximation with a (*) Coulomb potential; that model of this process is based on quantum tunneling and was developed by Gamow. The half-life is related to the energy released by this process according to the Geiger-Nuttall Law. This process decreases the mass number by four and the atomic number by two. For 10 points, name this decay method in which an atom decays by emitting a helium nucleus.

Young girls in this play sing “dress of jasmine, tie of crystal” while winding a skein of wool and asking it “what would you be?” Another song in this play about a dying stallion who won’t drink water is sung by a woman who criticizes her son for snapping at a girl who rhapsodizes over patterned silk stockings. A monologue in this play begins “white swan in the river, the eye of cathedrals, false dawn in the leaves.” A man asks his mother for a knife in this play to cut grapes, but this causes her to remember the (*) death of her husband. The Moon speaks in this play in which three woodcutters describe the hunt for Leonardo Felix, who runs off into the forest to elope with an engaged woman. For 10 points, name this first play in the “Rural Trilogy” by Federico Garcia Lorca about the Bride and Groom.
tossups.answer: Blood Wedding [or Bodas de Sangre or Wedding of Blood]

tossups.question: The third movement rondo of a trio sonata for this instrument, oboe, and piano was modeled after Saint-Saens's second piano concerto; that work was composed by Francis Poulenc. John Williams wrote a concerto called The Five Sacred Trees for Judith LeClair, who is currently the New York Phil’s principal chair for this instrument. A lengthy melody by this instrument can be heard in the entirety of the fourth movement of Shostakovich’s Ninth Symphony, and this instrument first plays the main melody of (*) “The Story of the Kalendar Prince” from Scheherazade. This instrument introduces the full main theme representing the walking brooms in The Sorcerer’s Apprentice. For 10 points, name this double-reed woodwind instrument that plays an unusually high solo at the beginning of The Rite of Spring.

Margaret MacMillan’s most famous book, subtitled “Six Months That Changed the World,” is about this event. Wellington Koo refused to sign on during this event when his country failed to regain territory. The Megali Idea of PM Venizelos was boosted by territory promised in it. An attempt to add a “racial equality clause” during this event was shot down by the opposition of Billy Hughes. During this event, John Foster Dulles helped draft the infamous Article (*) 231. Foreign Minister Sidney Sonnino was angry when his country did not gain the city of Fiume in this event. Poland received a “corridor” to get access to the sea during this event. Vittorio Orlando walked out of this event for a month despite being part of the “Big Four.” For 10 points, name this series of negotiations involving Lloyd George and George Clemenceau that led to a namesake treaty ending World War I.
tossups.answer: 1919 Versailles Peace Conference [or Paris peace conference]

tossups.question: A model of this process was generalized by Gerola and Seiden and states that this process propagates through shockwaves generated by stellar winds; that model is SSPSF. An exponent of 1.4 is used to relate the rate of this process to the local gas surface density in the Kennicutt-Schmidt law. This process occurs in regions that have a high infrared excess in a color-color diagram. UV emission into (*) H II regions can propagate this process. T tauri variables can result from this process, which commonly occurs in Bok globules. This process begins after the collapse of a giant molecular cloud, and the result of this process then moves along the H-R diagram. For 10 points, name this process that mainly occurs in stellar nurseries.
tossups.answer: star formation [accept reasonable equivalents like “the creation of a star” or “a star is born”]

tossups.question: Nancy Frishberg argued that these constructs reject the Steady State theory since they have become less iconic and more arbitrary over time. The tabula, designator, and signation were combined into cheremes to describe and represent these constructs by William Stokoe, an advocate for their legitimacy. One of these structures was spontaneously developed at a Nicaraguan school, while another was created by Charles-Michel de l’Epee. Oliver Sacks discussed how (*) “movement parsing” involved in learning these constructs changes the auditory cortex and described a protest by college students using these constructs at Gallaudet University in his book Seeing Voices. Martha’s Vineyard famously developed one of these systems for communication. For 10 points, name these systems of language often used by the deaf, including ASL.

A character in this story has a mole at the corner of her left eye and wears a scarf that makes her look like a Bodhisattva. One character in this story faints at “a cold light, a look of loathing” in her husband’s eyes. Another man releases a prisoner while saying “My fate is next”; that prisoner “sank down into the darkness of space” while dying. In this story, “the man in blue silk” lures another aside with the promise of swords and mirrors buried in a mound. The (*) amount of arrows in a man’s quiver and the fate of a sword are left uncertain in this story. In this story, Masago confesses to mercy-killing her husband Takehiko, but the ghost of Takehiko claims that she asked a robber who raped her to kill him. That robber, Tajomaru, is arrested at the end. For 10 points, name this short story in which contradicting testimonies are given for a murder, by Ryunosuke Akutagawa.

A former interim president of this country is now a professor of international development at the Indiana University in Bloomington and wrote Beyond Plunder about it. This country’s 2005 election was lost by former soccer star George Weah. One leader in this home of Amos Sawyer was supported by the song “he killed my ma, he killed my pa, I’ll vote for him.” A more unfortunate leader of it was videotaped while his ear was cut off by Prince (*) Johnson. Another leader of this country supported a rebel group in a western neighbor founded by Foday Sankoh that used child soldiers and blood diamonds. This country provided assistance to the Revolutionary United Front when led by brutal warlord Charles Taylor. For 10 points, name this African country which was founded by American freed slaves.

This figure’s father had camel placenta dumped on him by bullies, but this figure kindly cleaned it off. This figure’s dowry was paid by her poor future husband selling his shield, but that shield was then returned to him as a wedding gift. In Iran, the holiday commemorating this figure’s birthday supplanted International Women’s Day. A practice named for this person consists of reciting three different statements 34, 33, and 33 times respectively; that practice is this woman’s (*) tasbih. This woman was the only female member of the ahl al-bayt according to some Muslims. This woman’s children include Zainab, Hasan, and Husayn. For 10 points, name this wife of Ali and sole source of surviving male descendants of Khadija and the prophet Muhammad.

bonuses.leadin: Name some things about circuit components, for 10 points each:
parts: These components’ namesake value can be found by reading the four colored bands on their side. According to Ohm’s Law, the current flowing through them is equivalent to voltage divided by their namesake property.

These things, often used by hobbyist circuit-builders, are used to temporarily hold resistors and other circuit elements in place. These small boards provide connected rails for power and ground into which wires can easily slot.

These devices take in an inverting and non-inverting input, and are used to impose a gain on a low-amplitude signal or take the difference between two signals. Their ideal version is considered to have infinite input impedance.

bonuses.leadin: According to Aristotle, this thinker showed that philosophy isn’t useless after he used astronomy to make money off of a bumper crop of olives. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: the paths of is and is-not [or “estin and ouk estin”; accept equivalents like “being and nonbeing”]
parts: Name this Milesian who reportedly predicted a solar eclipse. He believed that the earth floats on water, and that water was the basic stuff of the universe.

Parmenides challenged contemporary natural theories by arguing that change was impossible, since all search for truth branched into these two paths. Only the second, forbidden path allowed for change. Name both.
This Abderan philosopher and his teacher Leucippus believed that the universe was comprised of void and uniform, unchanging, tiny things called atomos, or “uncuttable.”

bonuses.leadin: One woman in this novel bizarrely commits suicide by adorning her naked body with brightly colored lead paints. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Ella Minnow Pea: A Progressively Lipogrammatic Epistolary Fable [or Ella Minnow Pea: A Novel in Letters]
parts: Name this epistolary novel by Mark Dunn, in which letters are gradually excluded from the text as the government of Nollop bans them from use.
This symbol fails to occur in A Void, an Oulipo lipogrammatic book about Amaury Conson’s hunt for Anton Vowl. It also is famously lacking in Gadsby and this bonus part.

A Void was written by Oulipo member Georges Perec, who mainly wrote in this language. It is also the language of Exercises in Style and One Hundred Million Million Poems by another Oulipan, Raymond Queneau.

bonuses.leadin: This person employed the help of the right wing Freikorps to crush a Communist uprising, but the Freikorps turned on him in the Kapp Putsch. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Spartacist uprising [or January uprising; Spartakusbund uprising; Spartakusaufstand; Januaraufstand]
Weimar Republic [or Weimarer Republik; Weimar Germany]
parts: Name this first person who was succeeded as President of his country by Paul von Hindenburg. This person’s tenure saw the Allied occupation of the Ruhr and a severe bout of hyperinflation.

The Communist uprising Ebert crushed using the Freikorps had this name. The group which perpetrated this event published a newspaper called “The Red Flag” and was led by Rosa Luxembourg and Karl Liebknecht.
The Spartacist uprising sought to topple this interwar German government. This government’s economic weaknesses allowed it to be taken over by Adolf Hitler.

bonuses.leadin: Animals in this genus are some of the few flightless birds to possess a helmet-like “casque.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: cassowary [or Casuarius; also accept Dwarf cassowary; Southern cassowary; Northern cassowary]
cane toads [prompt on just “toads”; or Rhinella marina]
parts: Name this genus of flightless bird that uses its dagger-like, 5 inch-long middle toe to defend itself from predators. It is sometimes called the “most dangerous bird in the world.”

The extant wild cassowary population mostly resides in Papua New Guinea and this other country. In 1932, this country attempted to eradicate another flightless bird species in the so-called “Emu War.”
Today, Australia is attempting to eradicate its population of this invasive toad species, which was ironically introduced to the country to contain its beetle population.

bonuses.leadin: Name some things about prophets in Ancient Greece, for 10 points each:
parts: Because she rejected Apollo, this woman was gifted with prophecy but cursed to never be believed, such as when she predicted the fall of Troy.
Cassandra taught this man, her twin brother, the art of prophecy. Since people believed him, he told the Greeks to steal the Trojan Palladium and get Neoptolemus to join the war.
Another prophet, Tiresias, was able to tell Zeus and Hera about whether men or women enjoyed sex more because he was turned into a woman after hitting two of these animals with a stick.

bonuses.leadin: The third of these quantities defines the onset of soil liquefaction. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these quantities. The plastic type of these quantities is defined as the water content at which a soil can no longer be deformed by rolling into 3.2 mm diameter threads without crumbling.
Soil liquefaction is usually caused by these events, since the shaking of the ground produced by them causes the water pressure to exceed the forces that hold soil grains in contact with each other.
Soils that are poorly graded are more susceptible to liquefaction. This makes soils of this type, which contain particles that are between silt and gravel in size, highly susceptible to liquefaction.

bonuses.leadin: The artist who painted this work wrote a poem complaining that his stomach is squashed under his chin, he’s gotten a goiter, and paint keeps dripping onto his face. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Sistine Chapel ceiling [prompt on partial answer, accept synonyms]
tomb of Pope Julius II [prompt on partial answer, accept synonyms]
parts: Name this location painted by Michelangelo with scenes including The Separation of Light and Darkness and The Creation of Adam.

Michelangelo was originally commissioned for this work, but Bramante and Raphael persuaded Julius II to have him paint the Sistine Chapel instead. Michelangelo did create Moses and the Dying Slave for this work.
These 20 male figures with fig leaf garments on the Sistine Chapel ceiling are depicted in all-different sitting poses at the corner of the center narrative scenes.

bonuses.leadin: One of this author’s works begins “Once upon a time, say, circa 1980” and features a character who “thought of or-gates and of and-gates / of ROMs, of nor-gates, and of nand-gates.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Indian author who wrote about Rupa Mehra’s striving to get her daughter Lata married to the titular Suitable Boy.

Seth used Onegin couplets to write about the relationships of San Francisco yuppies Liz, Janet, and John, whose claim that “The Dow-Jones of my heart’s depressed” leads him to place a lonelyhearts ad.

In the Golden Gate, Phil and Liz attend Father O’Hare’s demonstrations against these things at Lungless Labs. Seth wrote a poem from the viewpoint of a doctor affected by one of these in In Other Voices.

bonuses.leadin: The title of a 1968 Ebony magazine essay by Lerone Bennet asks: “Was [this historical figure] A White Supremacist?” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln
John Milton Hay OR John George Nicolay
parts: Name this president who has been defended from Bennet’s charge by historians like Eric Foner. Foner’s book The Fiery Trial chronicles his acceptance of abolitionism and issuance of the Emancipation Proclamation.
This Pulitzer Prize-winning study of Lincoln by Doris Kearns Goodwin examines Lincoln’s sometimes fractious relationship with his Cabinet members, all of whom wanted Lincoln’s job.
One of the earliest critical biographies of Lincoln was a 10-volume biography written by two men, Lincoln’s personal secretaries during the Civil War. Name either man.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name some things about influential texts in music theory:
parts: Jean-Philippe Rameau wrote an influential treatise on this technique of sounding multiple notes at once. It is sometimes referred to as the “vertical” aspect of music, contrasted with the “horizontal” melody.
This seminal work by Johannes Fux defined five species counterpoints that are still widely used today. It is written as a socratic dialogue between Aloysius and Josephus.

Years after Fux and Rameau, this American student of Nadia Boulanger wrote textbooks on both Counterpoint and Harmony. He composed the Lincoln Center Festival Overture as well as the ballet The Incredible Flutist.

bonuses.leadin: Isaiah 56:10 compares leaders of Israel to dogs with this quality. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: muteness [or dumbness; or anything that indicates inability to speak]
parts: Name this quality that describes Daniel during his vision until the angel touches him. Archangel Gabriel consigned Zechariah to this fate for doubting the news of John the Baptist’s birth.
This prophet is bound to his house and becomes unable to speak unless directly through God. He remains mute until the Babylonians sack Jerusalem seven years later, fulfilling his earlier prophecy.
This biblical animal is famously granted the ability to speak by an angel, after which it rebukes its owner for smacking it three times while he is on his way to curse Israel.

bonuses.leadin: The organization SWAPO gained its country’s independence largely through this battle. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this battle, a strategic victory for the FAPLA against UNITA. Cuban air support bombed the Calueque Dam during this battle, and a Tripartite Accord was signed in New York City after it.
The Battle of Cuito Cuanavale took place in this country during the civil war between its MPLA, FNLA, and UNITA parties.
The Battle of Cuito Cuanavale helped lead to the end of this system of state-sponsored repression of blacks in South Africa.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of this story gets married because she hates her job teaching, but is dismayed to find that her husband only married her because he wanted her to teach his daughters for free. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this story in which Baptista Trewthen marries Charles Stow right before an arranged marriage to Mr. Heddegan, only to go ahead with the arranged marriage when Charles drowns an hour after the wedding.
The author of “A Mere Interlude” also wrote this novel in which the title character has the child “Little Father Time” with Arabella Donn and later marries his cousin Sue Bridehead.
“A Mere Interlude” and Jude the Obscure were written by this author who wrote about the rise and fall of Michael Henchard in The Mayor of Casterbridge.

bonuses.leadin: This group won a battle at Radcot Bridge against Robert de Vere. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Richard II [prompt on “Richard of Bordeaux”; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this group that executed Simon Burley during the “Merciless Parliament.” This group included Thomas of Woodstock, Duke of Gloucester, and Thomas de Beauchamp, Earl of Warwick.
The Lords Appellant sought to overthrow this monarch, who earlier faced a rebellion in Kent for levying the poll tax.
The aforementioned Peasant’s Revolt of 1381 was led by this person, who was treacherously killed during negotiations at Smithfield.

bonuses.leadin: This man produced notable versions of Don Giovanni and The Magic Flute in the 1950s. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this opera producer, who is much better known for being afraid of horses when he was five years old after seeing a cart crash. That was ascribed to a horse with a white streak in its hair symbolizing his father.

Little Hans was studied by Sigmund Freud, who diagnosed him with a complex named after this ancient Greek figure, since he believed that Hans subconsciously wanted to kill his father and sleep with his mother.

In a much less ridiculous study of a small boy, Freud interpreted his grandson’s play at this game, in which he would throw away a toy and scream once it was gone, then excitedly shout “There!” after bringing it back.

bonuses.leadin: Name some things about fight or flight responses, for 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: chromaffin cells [do NOT accept enterochromaffin cells]
parts: Fight or flight is stimulated by this part of the autonomic nervous system, contrasted with the parasympathetic nervous system. Its neurons release acetylcholine to trigger the release of norepinephrine.
Many hormones released by the sympathetic nervous system, including epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine, belong to this class of hormones derived from tyrosine.

These cells in the medulla of the adrenal glands are activated by the sympathetic nervous system’s acetylcholine release from the splanchnic nerve to release epinephrine. They are also found in the organ of Zuckerlandl.

bonuses.leadin: Although he started out as a pianist, this man switched to drums when he played with Erroll Garner. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this drummer who, along with Horace Silver, founded the Hard Bop movement and was the first to record notable pieces in the movement such as “Moanin.”
Blakey led this influential Jazz band that at one point included Freddie Hubbard and Wayne Shorter. This band infused gospel and hard bop in its influential 1955 recording of “The Preacher.”

Blakey briefly hired this virtuoso trumpeter and his saxophonist brother Branford for The Jazz Messengers. This man’s early recordings such as J Mood and Black Codes from the Underground propelled him to instant fame.

bonuses.leadin: One of this author’s characters writes out his will on a roll of toilet paper when he is locked in a toilet overnight. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this playwright who wrote about the milquetoast Barney Cashman’s failed attempts to seduce various wacky women in Last of the Red Hot Lovers. He parodied Chekhov plays in The Good Doctor.
This most famous Neil Simon play has the fastidious Felix move in with the slob Oscar after Felix’s wife kicks him out. Oscar throws a plate of linguini at the wall in this play.

In this Neil Simon play, the elderly and cantankerous vaudeville team Lewis and Clark reunite to do a “Doctor’s office” sketch for television, but chaos ensues when they keep poking and spitting on each other.

bonuses.leadin: These compounds can react with ketenes to form beta-lactams in Staudinger synthesis. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these compounds that possess a carbon-nitrogen double bond. These compounds can be a Schiff base if the nitrogen is bonded to an alkyl group instead of a hydrogen.
Using this heterocyclic compound with formula (CH2)5NH will result in selective formation of enamines from ketones. This heterocycle is basically cyclohexane with one carbon replaced with nitrogen.
Like cyclohexane, piperidine adopts this energetically favorable conformation for a six-membered ring. Cyclohexane adopts boat, twist-boat and this other conformation.
